People Can Fly Studio Hit by Major Layoffs Amidst Industry Turmoil
In a trend reflecting the broader instability in the video game industry, People Can Fly, known for its work on titles like Outriders and Bulletstorm, has downsized its workforce significantly. Over 30 employees involved in the development of their latest project, codenamed Project Gemini, have been let go. This comes at a time when the industry is grappling with numerous layoffs across various companies.
The company made the difficult announcement after an initial report by Kotaku, noting that a group of 20 other staff members were reassigned to different internal projects while parting ways with their colleagues. Adam Alker, the development director at People Can Fly, expressed heartfelt thanks to those leaving for their commitment and assured them of support during their transition.
The Polish developer, apart from its significant layoff news, has made a mark with the release of Bulletstorm VR in 2024 and Green Hell VR in 2022. Outriders, their 2021 collaborative project with Square Enix, had a tepid reception. The recent staff changes, particularly in Project Gemini, have brought up concerns about possible downscaled game features and delays in its scheduled 2026 release.
The layoff at People Can Fly is part of a distressing pattern hitting large and small studios alike. Significant names in the business like Microsoft, CD Projekt Red, Ubisoft, and Epic Games have all announced substantial workforce reductions, with entire studios such as Embracer’s Volition Games closing down.
The current environment within the video game industry points to a difficult year ahead, as developers and publishers alike navigate through economic uncertainties, which have already led to job losses and project reevaluations.
Summary: The video game industry continues to face a wave of layoffs, with People Can Fly becoming the latest studio to downsize its staff. Over 30 employees have been cut amidst the studio’s ongoing development of Project Gemini. This is part of an alarming trend of layoffs and studio closures affecting several major players in the gaming sector.
FAQ Section:
What has happened at People Can Fly recently?
People Can Fly has significantly downsized its workforce, laying off over 30 employees who were involved in the development of their latest project, codenamed Project Gemini.
Why were employees laid off at People Can Fly?
The layoffs at People Can Fly reflect broader instability in the video game industry, where numerous companies are dealing with layoffs due to economic uncertainties.
Were any employees reassigned at People Can Fly?
Yes, a group of 20 staff members were reassigned to different internal projects while the company parted ways with a number of their colleagues.
Has People Can Fly recently released any notable games?
Yes, the company released Bulletstorm VR in 2024 and Green Hell VR in 2022. However, their 2021 collaborative project with Square Enix, Outriders, received a tepid reception.
What are the concerns surrounding the recent layoffs and Project Gemini?
The staff changes at People Can Fly, particularly within the team of Project Gemini, have raised concerns about potential downscaled features and delays in the game’s scheduled release in 2026.
Is this downsizing unique to People Can Fly?
No, it is part of a wider trend of layoffs and studio closures occurring across the video game industry, affecting large and small studios, including major players like Microsoft, CD Projekt Red, Ubisoft, and Epic Games.
Are there any concerns for the video game industry going forward?
The industry is facing a difficult year due to economic uncertainties, which have led to job losses and project reevaluations.
Key Term Definitions:
– Downsizing: The process of reducing the number of employees on the staff of a company, often due to economic pressures.
– Layoffs: The termination of employees from their jobs, typically as a cost-saving measure during financial strain or organizational restructuring.
– Project Gemini: The codename for a video game currently in development by People Can Fly.
